project.teaser: Glycoscience is a multidisciplinary research area focusing on the role of glycans in health and disease. The field is expanding rapidly worldwide, driving innovation in biomedical sciences and becoming an essential part of modern science, including medicine, and providing...
project.objective: Glycoscience is a multidisciplinary research area focusing on the role of glycans in health and disease. The field is expanding rapidly worldwide, driving innovation in biomedical sciences and becoming an essential part of modern science, including medicine, and providing bases for understanding human diseases and tools for personalized medicine. GLYCOTwinning is a capacity-building network with the ambitious goal to provide a breakthrough in the research of the Applied Biomolecular Sciences Unit, NOVA University Lisbon (UCIBIO-NOVA), from chemistry to microbiology, immunology and biomedicine. To achieve excellence, UCIBIO-NOVA needs further synergies, to be acquired through networking with top-class partners: IMPERIAL, LUMC and CICbioGUNE. GLYCOTwinning will i) Promote scientific excellence and innovation in Glycoscience; ii) Empower researchers capacity and creativity; iii) Strengthen research management and administration skills; iv) Raise dissemination activities; v) Boost reputation, research profile and attractiveness. GLYCOTwinning brings synergy and multidisciplinarity in cutting-edge scientific methodologies: glycan microarrays, advanced electrophoresis, high-resolution mass spectrometry and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, to decode sugar recognition by glycan-binding proteins involved in disease. Through GLYCOTwinning, UCIBIO-NOVA will reinforce its research capacity, expanding its current R&D+I profile to dissect glycan-protein interactions, from the atomic and molecular levels to the cellular context, boosting the development of innovative glycan-based tools, diagnosis, and therapies. Furthermore, GLYCOTwinning will integrate its objectives in a project that explores glycan-protein interactions of the human microbiome in colorectal cancer, validating a GLYCOTwinning ToolBox, creating new knowledge, innovation and opening new research avenues for the widest dissemination and exploitation, with long term scientific and societal impact.
project.title: GLYCOTwinning: Building Networks to Excel in Glycosciences
project.keywords: glycan-protein interactions, glycan recognition, lectins and adhesins, cancer and microbiome

article.title: Sweetening the deal: enhancing glycans research capacity in Lisbon

result.title: Mucin Glycoprotein Microarray towards Glycan Ligand discovery for CBMs of Human Gut Microbiota

details.authors: Filipa TROVÃO, Jodie ABRAHAMS, Antonio D I MAIO, Jin YU, Wengang CHAI , Ana Luísa CARVALHO, Ten FEIZI, Yan LIU, Angelina S. PALMA

result.title: 1st Summer School
result.description: Summer School (4 days) covering challenges, state of the art and/or advanced methodologies, hands-on sessions with tutorials and talks by external leaders.1st SS will focus on glycan microarray technologies and glyco-bionformatics tools.

result.title: Brochure and reports for outreach activities
result.description: Planned outreach, communication and dissemination materials, scheduled for M17 and M36.These will include:1) A brochure about the GLYCOTwinning consortium (M8) to be distributed in outreach events (e.g. European Researchers’ Night) 2) A “GLYCOTwinning Scientific Café” organized on the occasion of the Annual Youth Week in Almada. 3) High-school visits to the GLYCOTwinning laboratories during Open days at FCT-NOVA. 4) Participation in informal meetings as “PubPhD de Lisboa”; 5) “Café with Patients” (just after the 2nd WTSS) a special session of effective Patient-centered communication.

result.title: GLYCOTwinning Newsletter
result.description: 6-monthly newsletter, distributed online, to share: i) developments in Glycoscience fields, ii) results achieved by the consortium, iii) upcoming project events, iv) outcomes of past activities and v) researchers’ profile.

result.title: THE IMPACT OF DEFECTIVE HOST CELL GLYCOSYLATION IN BACTERIAL INFECTION

details.publisher: Instituto de Tecnologia Química e Biológica António Xavier. Universidade NOVA de Lisboa

result.title: Joint Lab Retreats
result.description: Three joint lab retreats (M12, M24, M36) between NOVA researchers and partners group leaders.Will include scientific discussions, and brainstorming on the recent advances in glycochemistry, glycobiology and glycomics to boost new and transforming ideas in cancer and microbiome.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
